docs.lead_paragraph: MEN and women are affected differently by their access -- or lack of it -- to the American health care system. Women use health care more, spend a greater portion of their income on it and are more likely to come into contact with the health care system than other family members, according to a study released earlier this month by the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. The study found that women are "chronically uninsured," because their life-cycle and labor participation patterns often preclude coverage by an employer. Three-quarters of the nation's 12 million uninsured women are employed but do not receive insurance at work, the study found.

headline.main: At Work; Unhealthy Prospects for Women
